channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: How Boko Haram Trains Abducted Women and Girls to Be Suicide Bombers
item.description: Of all the many horrors of Boko Haram’s rampage, one of the most baffling has been its ability to turn captured women and girls into killers.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:description: Rahila Amos, a Nigerian grandmother, said she was abducted by Boko Haram and forced to take classes on how to carry out a suicide bombing.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Blaming Policy, Not Islam, for Belgium’s Radicalized Youth
item.description: For Yves Goldstein, a councilman in Brussels, allowing ethnic ghettos to grow unchallenged created the perfect recruiting ground for Islamists.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Schaerbeek neighborhood in Brussels. Salah Abdeslam, the Islamic State recruit who participated in the Paris terror attacks, sought refuge in the neighborhood for weeks.

item.title: Vladimir Putin Says Allegations in Panama Papers Are an American Plot
item.description: In his first remarks on the subject, the Russian leader also defended the cellist Sergei P. Roldugin, a friend who was named in the reports about the leaked documents.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Dmitry Astakhov/Sputnik / Kremlin
item.media:description: From left, the cellist Sergei P. Roldugin, Vladimir V. Putin and Dmitry Medvedev at the House of Music in St. Petersburg in 2009.

item.title: Belgian Police Release New Video of Brussels Airport Suspect
item.description: The footage provides a first look at how the “man in the hat” left the building right after the bombings, and where he went.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and LILIA BLAISE

item.title: Malaysia Panel Calls for Investigation of Former Head of 1MDB Fund
item.description: Members of the state investment fund’s board of directors said they would offer their resignation after a parliamentary committee released its report.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.media:description: The police seizing equipment from the office of 1Malaysia Development Berhad, the state investment fund, in Kuala Lumpur, the capital, last year.

item.title: Izmir Journal: Path to Greece Closed, Economy of Smugglers and Others Suffers in Turkey
item.description: Basmane Square in Izmir, its businesses and streets once teeming with migrants, has grown quiet since Greece has begun sending migrants back to Turkey.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: Migrants trying to negotiate with smugglers packed the area around the Sinbad restaurant in Basmane Square in Izmir, Turkey, in September. But this week, days after Greece began sending migrants back to Turkey under a contentious deal with the European Union, it was mostly empty.

item.title: As Graft Cases in Chile Multiply, a ‘Gag Law’ Angers Journalists
item.description: A new law would punish anyone who makes public information about current judicial investigations with up to 541 days in prison.
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY
item.media:description: Pablo Longueira, a former finance minister, in 2013, when he was a presidential candidate for the U.D.I. Party. Mr. Longueira resigned from his party last month.

item.title: Secular Bangladeshi Activist Is Latest to Be Killed After Criticizing Islamists
item.description: Men armed with machetes surrounded the activist, Mohammad Nazim Uddin, and slashed his head, then shot him, a police official said.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and MAHER SATTAR
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A police officer in Bangladesh on Thursday near the site where a secular activist, Mohammad Nazim Uddin, was killed the night before.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Politics of Me
item.description: Politics has come home to the body. I change the planet, therefore I am.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: How Pope Francis’ ‘Amoris Laetitia’ Could Affect Families and the Church
item.description: The document could change church practice on divisive subjects like holy communion for those who remarry, same-sex relationships, cohabitation and polygamy.
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving for his weekly audience in St. Peter’s Square at the Vatican on Wednesday. On Friday, he is expected to issue a long-awaited statement on the family.

item.title: Sinosphere: Calvin Trillin’s Poem on Chinese Food Proves Unpalatable for Some
item.description: Critics said Mr. Trillin’s poem in The New Yorker — titled “Have They Run Out of Provinces Yet?” — reflected fear and ignorance of China.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Christian Hansen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The writer Calvin Trillin, center, at an after-party in New York at the restaurant China Grill. He has written extensively about cuisine, including Chinese food in the United States.

item.title: Report Ties U.S. Bombs to Saudi-Led Strike That Killed Yemeni Civilians
item.description: Human Rights Watch said it had found fragments of American-made bombs at a Yemeni market where at least 97 civilians died, including 25 children.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and C. J. CHIVERS

item.title: Panama Papers Leak Casts Light on a Law Firm Founded on Secrecy
item.description: Ramón Fonseca, a co-founder of Mossack Fonseca, proclaimed his firm’s innocence. But some say the leak’s contents are at odds with how he has tried to portray himself and his role in Panama.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE, AZAM AHMED and ERIC LIPTON
item.media:description: Panama City on Monday. The president of Panama has vowed to cooperate with investigations over a law firm’s leaked documents.

item.title: Editorial: Tensions Rise in the South China Sea
item.description: China’s neighbors are supported by the United States in opposing Beijing’s bullying tactics over territorial claims.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:description: Japanese destroyers and a submarine docked at a port in the Philippines near disputed South China Sea waters.

item.title: Dutch Referendum Leads to Defeat of E.U.-Ukraine Trade Deal
item.description: Voters in the Netherlands said no to a trade and cooperation pact. All 28 member countries must approve the deal.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: To Discourage Prostitution, France Passes Bill That Penalizes Clients
item.description: First-time offenders will pay a fine of about $1,700 if they “solicit, accept or obtain relations of a sexual nature.” The fine can rise to about $4,300 for repeat offenders.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Iran Plans Visit to Rival Saudis to Discuss Hajj Pilgrimage
item.description: It would be a rare official meeting between Iran and Saudi Arabia, which broke relations in January after protesters burned the Saudi Embassy in Tehran.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Bodies were gathered in Mina, Saudi Arabia, near Mecca, after a stampede in September killed hundreds of Muslim pilgrims.

item.title: Executions Highest in 25 Years, Amnesty International Says
item.description: At least 1,634 people were executed in 2015, the group found, an increase of more than 50 percent over 2014 and the highest since 1989.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Facebook Groups Act as Weapons Bazaars for Militias
item.description: Facebook posts suggest evidence of large-scale efforts to buy and sell weapons as large as guided missiles in the Middle East and North Africa.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: An account on Facebook uploaded a picture with text that read “Libya Weapons Market.”

item.title: Jacob Zuma, Under Siege, Finds Political Refuge in Rural South Africa
item.description: As urban South Africans call for his resignation, the president remains popular in the villages and towns that are his party’s stronghold.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:credit: Sbusisiwe Magwaza/Government Communication & Info System, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: President Jacob G. Zuma of South Africa, right, visiting Melmoth, a small town in the country’s southeast, on Sunday.
